newsitem.title: USA: Price Communications to buy Palmer Wireless for $880 million.
newsitem.headline: Price Communications to buy Palmer Wireless for $880 million.

text.p: Palmer Wireless Inc., a Southeastern cellular telephone provider, said Friday it agreed to be aquired by Price Communications Corp. for $17.50 per share in cash, or a total of $880 million.
Palmer's stock shot up $3.94 to $16 early on Nasdaq. Price, based in New York, fell 25 cents to $9.125 on the American Stock Exchange.
Analysts said the deal is part of a growing trend toward consolidation in the wireless industry.
A spokesman for Palmer that $489 million of the price tag covers stock and options. The rest is for repayment of debt.

"Since our initial public offering in March 1995, we have significantly increased the size and scope of our operations, and have strived to maximize value to all our shareholders," said William Ryan, president and chief executive of Palmer.

Palmer Wireless, based in Ft. Myers, Fla., owns and operates 18 non-wireline cellular telephone systems in Florida, Alabama, Georgia and South Carolina. All of the company's systems are part of the North American Cellular Network and are Cellular One affiliates.
The agreement is expected to close in the fourth quarter, subject to regulatory approval.
"We expect massive (merger and acquisition) activity in the wireless services sector," Steven Yanis, an analyst at Salomon Brothers Inc., said in a report.

"We believe the Palmer deal is relatively early within the trend and while the price is significantly higher than the current stock price, we believe Price Communications is also entering into an attractive deal."
